author: Matthew Kronsberg
title: Why Butcher Shops Make Great Restaurants
text:
1 COMMENTS NORMALLY, IF YOU leave a restaurant with food, that food has already been cooked. But at a growing number of hybrid restaurant-butcher shops, diners have the option of leaving not just with doggie bags, but with raw ingredients and a side of inspiration.
Related Recipe ENLARGE Jason Varney for The Wall Street Journal Recipe: Country-Style Pork Ribs That’s how it works at Kensington Quarters, in Philadelphia’s Fishtown neighborhood. “As customers walk in,” said executive chef Damon Menapace, “the first thing they see is the butcher shop, with all that meat on display. They have a nice meal, hopefully try some things that they never would have thought to try, and then think to themselves, ‘I could probably do this.’ ”
Broadening customers’ dining—and cooking—horizons is a natural part of the “whole-animal” style of butchery that most of these new restaurants practice. “With something like pig trotters, it’s a way easier sell if I prepare them,” said John Blevins, co-owner of Clove & Hoof in Oakland, Calif. (using the menu-friendly name for pigs’ feet). But a customer who tries them in Mr. Blevins’s restaurant may thereafter be more inclined to buy them at his butcher’s counter to cook at home.
ENLARGE Kensington Quarters dining room Photo: Jason Varney for The Wall Street Journal ENLARGE Charcuterie at Kensington Quarters Photo: Jason Varney for The Wall Street Journal Less adventurous diners, too, can benefit from the combination of skilled butchery and inventive chefery practiced at these places. At Parts & Labor in Baltimore, one of the big sellers, both in the restaurant and in the shop, is the “cattleman steak,” a craftily rebranded and crowd-pleasing cut taken from just above the knuckle or knee of the steer. And at Clove & Hoof, Mr. Blevins is particularly proud of their cheeseburger, which, like many great restaurant burgers, is made extra succulent thanks to ground beef with a higher fat content than many butchers would dare display. “Otherwise,” he said, “it’s just meatloaf.”
At Kensington Quarters, Mr. Menapace revels in the collaborative atmosphere that comes with in-house butchery. “The kitchen’s open, so all morning while we’re prepping, we’re talking back and forth with the butcher shop,” he said. “They’re coming into the kitchen, saying, ‘Can you throw this onto the stove to test it?’ It’s really kind of like a dream for a chef.” And, potentially, a game-changer for a home cook, too.
Choice Cuts // Top Butcher Shop-Restaurants Around the Country Parts & Labor, Baltimore
James Beard award-winning chef Spike Gjerde brings locally raised meat to Charm City, with a full charcuterie program and an ever changing selection of unusual cuts. partsandlaborbutchery.com
ENLARGE Owners John Blevins and Analiesa Gosnell at Clove & Hoof in Oakland, Calif. Photo: Clove & Hoof Clove & Hoof Butchery, Oakland, Calif.
A recently launched dinner service will allow the restaurant to expand beyond the sandwiches that have already garnered a devoted following. cloveandhoofoakland.com
Kensington Quarters, Philadelphia
Along with the bustling restaurant, bar and shop, cooking and butchery classes are offered. kensingtonquarters.com
Dai Due, Austin, Texas
After years of hosting pop-up Supper Club dinners and selling meat at local farmers’ markets, Dai Due finally has a permanent home, where Austinites can feast on owner Jesse Griffiths’s superlative sausages and dishes like venison paprikash. daidue.com
Fleishers Craft Kitchen, Westport, Conn.
The first restaurant from a growing family of “whole-animal” butcher shops in Connecticut and New York features classics like steak frites as well as soon-to-be classics, like the “crispy pig” platter with chicharrones and crunchy strips of fried pig ear. fleishers.com
